qas.question: What country held a prominent place in the revival movement?
What orator was very famous during the revival movement?
When was the province of France canonically erected?
What title did Pere Vincent Jandel hold during this time?
What country held a minor place in the revival movement?
What orator was not well known during the revival movement?
What year did Jean-Baptiste Henri Lacordaire take the habit of a Friar Preacher in Paris?
When was the province of England canonically erected?
What title did Pere Vincent Jandel not hold during this time?

context: In the revival movement <a0_0><b4_0>France<b4_0/><a0_0/> held a foremost place, owing to the reputation and convincing power of the orator, <a1_0><b5_0>Jean-Baptiste Henri Lacordaire<b5_0/><a1_0/> (1802–1861). He took the habit of a Friar Preacher at Rome (<b6_0>1839<b6_0/>), and the province of France was canonically erected in <a2_0><b7_0>1850<b7_0/><a2_0/>. From this province were detached the province of Lyon, called Occitania (1862), that of Toulouse (1869), and that of Canada (1909). The French restoration likewise furnished many laborers to other provinces, to assist in their organization and progress. From it came the <a3_0><b8_0>master general<b8_0/><a3_0/> who remained longest at the head of the administration during the 19th century, Père Vincent Jandel (1850–1872). Here should be mentioned the province of St. Joseph in the United States. Founded in 1805 by Edward Fenwick, afterwards first Bishop of Cincinnati, Ohio (1821–1832), this province has developed slowly, but now ranks among the most flourishing and active provinces of the order. In 1910 it numbered seventeen convents or secondary houses. In 1905, it established a large house of studies at Washington, D.C., called the Dominican House of Studies. There are now four Dominican provinces in the United States.
